greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = number of distinct prime factors of n that are > the square of smallest prime factor of n, a(1) = 0.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10001
formula: a(n) = Sum_{p|n, p prime and > spf(n)^2} sign(p), where spf(n) (A020639) gives the smallest prime factor of n, and sign(p) = A057427(p) = 1 for all p.
example: For n = 50, 2*5*5, the prime factor > 2^2 is 5, which is counted only once, thus a(50) = 1.
For n = 70, 2*5*7, the prime factors > 2^2 are 5 and 7, thus a(70) = 2.
mathematica: Table[If[n == 1, 0, Count[#, d_ /; d > First[#]^2] &@ FactorInteger[n][[All, 1]]], {n, 120}] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Mar 24 2017 *)
program: A(n) = if(n<2, return(1), my(f=factor(n)[, 1]); for(i=2, #f, if(f[i]>f[1]^2, return(f[i]))); return(1));
for(n=1, 150, print1(omega(a(n)),", ")) \\ _Indranil Ghosh_, after _David A. Corneth_, Mar 24 2017
def a(n): return 1 if A(n)==1 else A(n)*a(n//A(n))
print([omega(a(n)) for n in range(1, 151)]) # _Indranil Ghosh_, Mar 24 2017
xref: Cf. A251726 (gives the positions of zeros after the initial a(1)=0).
Differs from related A284256 for the first time at n=50, where a(50)=1, while A284256(50)=2.
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Mar 24 2017
